knowledge_zone.heading: First-Person Narration: Creates meaning in the text

sections.content: First-Person Narration is used throughout the text to creates meaning in the text.

examples.quote: but it was not until Sebastian
examples.scene: Opening reflection on aesthetic education through Sebastian
examples.effect: Establishes retrospective voice that transforms personal memory into universal meditation on discovery and loss

examples.quote: I was no fool; I was old enough to know
examples.scene: Charles reflects on Lady Marchmain's attempt to influence him
examples.effect: Retrospective voice combines personal memory with mature judgment, transforming individual experience into universal meditation on manipulation and loss of innocence

examples.quote: Through and through is a long way, madam
examples.scene: Charles's internal monologue while conversing with elderly woman at party
examples.effect: Limited retrospective narration reveals the narrator's subjective interiority, transforming surface social interaction into deeper meditation on unknowable self

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use First-Person Narration HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
